comment_text:
Its kind of frightening how many people missed the point of this video.

So let me explain:

They were newly married, obviously in financial stress if shopping at a dented can grocery store, and she went to the trouble of shopping and cooking dinner for him. Dustin chose to acknowledge her labor and love for him and ate the bad food without complaint. She knew it was bad, she knew he thought it was bad too, but he communicated something much deeper and more loving by his actions than he could have by words. In that moment, in that time of stress in their lives, a gesture of unconditional love to his wife was much more powerful and wise than brutal honesty. There is a place for food criticism, and of course honesty is crucial in a marriage. But honesty wasnt needed, they both knew it was bad.

As for any of you who think he did it only so she would continue cooking for him, and not that he did it as an act of marital love, i cant fix your cynicism.

You've made some pretty amazing videos, but this one probably tops them all so far! What a fantastic bit of advice, and very much worth passing on. (My favorite hobby is collecting marriage tips and advice, and I have never met a couple yet who did not have something I could learn... good or bad)

Thank you for passing this on.

My uncle's marriage lasted 69 years, ended only by his death a few years ago. That advice has saved me much conflict over the years.

For the first month or so of our marriage, my wife would call me just before I got off work or immediately when I got home and ask what I wanted for dinner.
This would begin the 10- minute conversation with each of us asking what meal would suit our mood. (" I don't know. What do you feel like having?"

I was a desk supervisor at Kelly Temporary Services and office work was new to me and brought on a new level of stress.

Once day was particularly gruelling and when I arrived home she was eager to cook whatever I wanted. I sat her down and held her hand and explained, "Honey, I completely trust your cooking and after a day with making so many decisions that having to decide for our home what we should eat is frustrating. So, you cook it and I'll eat it." She never had to ask me again and there wasn't peace in our home. We.also agreed if & when she worked, whoever cooked, the other would clean. It was our proper arrangement. And it worked great.

I made sweet potato pie and casserole from my own garden. I made lasagna and I made soybean paste stew. Only one person joined me to eat those things - my friend who cooked with me. Not wanting to lie, but also not wanting to complain, our interaction went something like this:

Her: What do you think?
Me: It's... OK
Her: I think it awful, I don't want to eat it.
Me: Oh, good, I don't think it's very good either.
Her: Want to throw it away?

I've got a similar story as this.. kind off..

I have 3 siblings, 2 brothers one sister, When i was 8-10 years old i loved to help my mom make dinner, we made together some kind of small sized pizzas. They looked really good and i spent alot of time making them and i was super happy about it. The time came when i got to taste my own food and share it with my siblings. I thought the food was Ok, but they thought it was disgusting and they all threw it away after telling me it was disgusting, I did cry and i felt so bad about it. But this taught me a valuable lesson, I learned how it felt when you take your time and make food for someone, and they just say " its disgusting", this completely stopped me from wanting to make food for anyone but myself because i was afraid that they'd hate it. After this happened i never told my parents that i didnt like their food, i always ate what i was served and i said it tasted good and enjoyed it. And i do the same for all my friends ,regardless what they serve me, i eat it.


Please- IF a person,family member or friend, girlfriend/boyfriend takes alot of time and love to cook you something. Eat it ! it encourages them to make more food and learn. And more importantly.. dont say the food is disgusting.

This also reminded me of another story (I saw this on a video about marriage and it's a true story from an elderly couple).  In the interview they asked him what it takes to have a successful marriage (they were celebrating 50th wedding anniversary).  He replied... "The end of a loaf of bread is my favorite part, so, instead of eating it I would cut it, butter it up, and give it to her even though it was my favorite."  She laughed and completed his story by saying... "I hate that part of the bread, but because he put so much love and care on preparing it that I would eat it with a smile on my face."  Moral of the story:  "He offered his favorite part to his lovely wife and she received the offering with a smile even though she hated that part of the bread.  To make a relationship work you have to sometimes give away things you love and receive things you don't like... and if you do that with love your relationship will flourish."

When my parents were first married, my Mom, wanted to impress my Dad with her cooking. She worked most of the day making a Chicken Pie. When my Dad got home from work, he was surprised to see a beautiful Chicken Pie meal waiting for him, on the Kitchen table. As they sat down to eat, there was a problem. They couldn't cut the pie open. Try as they might, they couldn't get past the crust. Mom started to cry. "No problem dear, don't cry, I have an Idea", my Dad said. He went to the garage and came back with a hammer and a big screwdriver and preceded to chip away the crust. It seems Mom had left out the shortening, from the pie crust dough and it was hard as stone. They were married for 65 years and laughed about it till they passed away.
A True story.

Or do you throw it in the bin and tell them that their spelling is awful, and that dogs aren't blue?

Which you choose says much more about you than it does about the other person.

Man, that's the stuff, right there. My parents have a similar story, where my mom went to Dirty Don's (they sell expired or otherwise rejected goods at insane prices, and shoppers know the risks) and got some ravioli in a bag. My mom cooked it, very pregnant with my sister, suffering a gallbladder infection. I was (2 years old) wrapped head-to-heel in casts from a childhood accident, my dad was one-day-home recovering from brain surgery. It was a rough time, particularly for my momma.

The ravioli had maggots in it, but my poor mom didn't notice because she had a fever (they had elected to wait three weeks until my sister was born before surgery, my mom's as tough as any SEAL). My dad sat there, staring at maggots wriggling on his plate as mom went to the bathroom, probably to vomit, and when she came back he said "This looks really good, thank you, sweetheart". She appreciated that and told him so, feeling good about herself. When she sat down, my dad had the most forlorn, lost look on his face as he stared at that ravioli.

Mom looked at her own plate, then at his, and then laughed hard and loud at herself. They ate Italian take-out that night, and mom said she wanted my dad to always be honest about her cooking. She's a great cook, and we're not allowed to lie about it!

I’ve been here already with my fiancé. Long story:

We were living far apart, and still are for that matter, and I was flying in to spend my two weeks vacation with her.

I’d told her I hoped to get a taste of her home cooking, and she said she’d cook me a meal that would be ready when I arrived so she didn’t spend hours of our precious little time together cooking.

So I arrive, and she had fallen asleep after cooking, her phone was off and I’m in an airport two cities away in a foreign country where I don’t speak the language.

So I thought she was a little late and just waited at first. After a half hour I was worried. After an hour I started walking around, finally found someone I could communicate with and borrowed his phone. This is when I found it was going straight to voicemail. So I wait, and I agonized and tried her phone several more times. Finally she showed up, just before I got desperate enough to try to get a ride to her city. Now it’s so late though that she’s feeling sick so we stop and eat on the way back.

Hours later when it’s time for dinner, she says that she’ll just throw out the meal she made because now it’s gone stale. But I insisted we try it. She didn’t like it and could barely eat any. She’d made enough for three people, and I sat there under her incredulous gaze and ate it all. :-)

From your favorite Browning couple. My amazing husband completely won me over on this same subject. We were dating, I invited him over to eat a dinner that I would cook. I tried to create a meal my mom always made, slice of ham, slice of pineapple on top with melted cheese on top of that. However, I shopped at Aldi and did not realize that my ham was actually spam. So I sliced the spam, and then forgot to core the pineapple, so I had a pineapple with the core in it and then melted aldi cheese on top. My boyfriend at the time, (and now husband of almost 10 years) ate the entire plate and asked for 2nds. I thought it was awful and only took a few bites. Later that night, while watching shark week, he mentioned that most people take the core out of the pineapple, but he liked my spin on the meal. And when I realized it was spam and not ham, I was so embarrassed! But, Destin and Tara, your advice held true for our marriage too!

For all first time cooks, experiment, try to learn the basics, the big thing is flavors. Learn what flavors compliment each other, and flavors that counter act the others in the event of the accidental over seasoning (It will happen!). Look up "The Flavor Star" chart if you would like to see what I'm talking about. Cooking is both a science and an art, you can cook a given ingredient in a variety of different ways if you just think outside of the box. Don't be afraid to try new things, and in terms of spices, smell and taste them to get a database on what each thing will taste like.

There are so many "simple" rules for relationships.

My favorite was my maternal grandparent's rule to never go to bed angry with each other. They would either stay up all night talking things out, or just agree to disagree and calmly set it aside (never to be forgotten, but for tagged for further discussion).

They would also never argue (in the emotional sense) in front of family or guests. Verbally, that is. They would always prepare meals together, but when they were pissed with each other there'd be an excessive degree of "fanny bumping" in the kitchen, which the rest of us had to pretend to ignore for fear of bursting into belly laughs.

Bottom line, they were ALWAYS communicating, never giving each other the "silent treatment" or a "cold shoulder". No topic was ever off-limits. They also were open to us grandkids about what was going on, so we never feared their more intense discussions.

No kid could ask for a better example of a rich and dynamic adult relationship.

One Saturday when my girlfriend (now wife of 17 happy years) and I were in undergrad, I came home after being at work for fourteen hours. Similar situation, little money, no good ingredients available. Most days I cooked, but on Saturdays she would make dinner for me when I got home, usually something like pasta. This day she made something that I just couldn't eat, specifics unnecessary. I tried and at some point the, "hwuuuuh," vomiting sound came out.

I hear about it to this day when she cooks, and she uses that as an example of why she doesn't cook. I wish I could go back 18.5 years and tell myself what was coming with a dire warning to finish the damned food or else.

When I was dating, my now wife, she was in college and came home to visit.  She wanted to make my favorite meal (corned beef) for valentines day.  She knew she was going to be getting home from school late so she asked for suggestions on how to cook the meat faster.  She thought "I should ask the cafeteria guy at school!" He told her to just cut the meat thinner and it will cook faster.  So she went and got sliced corned beef from the deli counter.  When I arrived for dinner she was already boiling something in the huge pot.  When she dished it up.... it was just warm wet lunch meat. 15yrs later we still laugh about her trying to do a good deed and it turning out so poorly.
